Read you not the wrong you're doing

In my cheek's pale hue?

All my life with sorrow strewing;

Wed or cease to woo.
author: Thomas Campbell

quote: If I am not worth the wooing, I surely am not worth the winning.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: Men are April when they woo, December when they Wed.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The way of an eagle in the air; the way of a serpent upon a rock; the way of a ship in the midst of the sea; and the Way of a man with a maid.
author: Proverbs

quote:
She’s beautiful and therefore to be woo'd:

She is a woman, therefore to be won.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Why don't you speak for yourself, John?
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote:
Perhaps if you address the lady Most politely, most politely,

Flatter and impress the lady

Most politely, most politely,

Humbly beg and humbly sue,

She may deign to look on you.
author: William Schwenck Gilbert

quote:
The time I've lost in wooing,

In watching and pursuing

The light that lies

In woman's eyes,

Has been my heart's undoing.
author: Thomas Moore

quote: They dream in courtship, but in wedlock wake.
author: Alexander Pope

quote:
Sigh no more, ladies, sigh no more,

Men were deceivers ever,

One foot in sea and one on shore;

To one thing constant never.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
A fool there was and he made his prayer
(Even as you and F)
To a rag and a bone and a hank of hair
(We called her the woman who did not care) But the fool he called her his lady fair
(Even as you or 1!)
author: Rudyard Kipling

quote:
O gentle Romeo,

If thou dost love, pronounce it faithfully.

Or if thou think'st I am too quickly won,

I'll frown and be perverse and say thee nay,

So thou wilt woo: but else, not for the world.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Words of truth and soberness.
author: Acts

quote: A very great part of the mischiefs that vex this world arises from words.
author: Edmund Burke

quote: Mum is the word.
author: Miguel De Cervantes

quote: Let thy words be few.
author: The Book Of Ecclesiastes

quote: The society of women is the foundation of good manners.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote: Our words have wings, but fly not where we would.
author: George Eliot

quote: How forcible are right words!
author: Job, Bible

quote: Who is this that darkeneth counsel by words without knowledge?
author: Job, Bible

quote: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God and the Word was God.
author: John, Bible

quote: I am not yet so lost in lexicography, as to forget that words are the daughters of earth, and that things are the sons Of heaven.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: Words are the most powerful drug used by mankind.
author: Rudyard Kipling

quote:
Words should have a great many fewer disputes in the world
II words were taken for what they are, the signs of our ideas only, and not for things themselves.
author: John Locke

quote: Speaking words of endearment where words of comfort availed not.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: Words will build no walls.
author: Plutarch Lucius Mestrius Plutarchus

quote: A word spoken in good season, how good it is!
author: Proverbs

quote: A word fitly spoken is like apples of gold in pictures of silver.
author: Proverbs

quote: The words of his mouth were smoother than butter, but war was in his heart; his words were softer than oil, yet were they drawn swords.
author: The Book Of Psalms

quote: One of our defects as a nation is a tendency to use what have been called "weasel words." When a weasel sucks. eggs the meat is sucked out of the egg. If you use a "weasel' word" after another there is nothing left of the other.
author: Theodore Roosevelt

quote:
I sometimes hold it half a sin

To put in words the grief I feel;

For words, like Nature, half reveal

And half conceal the Soul within.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: You (Pindar) who possessed the talent of speaking much without saying anything.
author: Voltaire

quote:
My word fly up, my thoughts remain below:
Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: A word to the wise is sufficient.
author: Terence Publius Terentius Afer

quote:
But yesterday the word of Caesar might

Have stood against the world; now lies he there,

And none so poor to do him reverence.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Taffeta phrases, silken terms precise,
Three-piled hyperboles, spruce affectation,
Figures pedantical.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Hold fast the form of sound words.
author: Timothy

quote:
All Nature seems at work, slugs leave their lair—

The bees are stirring—birds are on the wing—

And Winter, slumbering in the open air,

Wears on his smiling face a dream of Spring!

And I the while, the sole unbusy thing,

Nor honey make, nor pair, nor build, nor sing.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: Handle your tools without mittens.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: All things are full of labour; man cannot utter it: the eye is not satisfied with seeing, nor the ear filled with hearing.
author: The Book Of Ecclesiastes

quote: I never did anything worth doing by accident, nor did any of my inventions come by accident; they came by work.
author: Thomas Alva Edison

quote: A ploughman on his legs is higher than a gentleman on his knees.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread.
author: Genesis, Bible

quote:
And only the Master shall praise us, and only the Master shall blame;

And no one shall work for money, and no one shall work for fame;

No each for the joy of the working, and each, in his separate star,

Shall draw the Thing as he sees It, for the God of things as They Are!
author: Rudyard Kipling

quote:
No man is born into the world whose work

Is not born with him; there is always work,

And tools to work withal, for those who will;

And blessed are the horny hands of toil!
author: James Russell Lowell

quote: The laborer is worthy of his hire.
author: Luke, Bible

quote:
How many a rustic Milton has passed by,

Stifling the speechless longings of his heart,

In unremitting drudgery and care!

How many a vulgar Cato has compelled

His energies, no longer tameless then,

To mould a pin, or fabricate a nail!
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote:
This is the best world, that we live in,

To lend and to spend and to give in:

But to borrow, or beg, or to get a man's own,

It is the worst world that ever was known.
author: Anonymous

quote: This world's a bubble.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Believe everything you hear said of the world; nothing is too impossibly bad.
author: Honore De Balzac

quote:
The year's at the Spring

And day's at the morn;

Morning's at seven;

The hillside's dew-pearled;

The lark's on the wing;

The snail's on the thorn:

God's in his Heaven

All's right with the world!
author: Robert Browning

quote:
I have not loved the world, nor the world me;

I have not flatter'd its rank breath, nor bow'd

To its idolatries a patient knee.
author: Lord Byron

quote: Socrates, indeed, when he was asked of what country he I ailed himself, said, "Of the world"; for he considered himself an inhabitant and a citizen of the whole world.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: Come, follow me, and leave the world to its babblings.
author: Durante Degli Alighieri Dante

quote:
Good-bye, proud world! I'm going home;

Thou are not my friend; I am not thine.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: The nations are as a drop of a bucket.
author: Isaiah

quote: World without end.
author: Isaiah

quote: It takes all sorts of people to make a world.
author: George Norman Douglas

quote:
The world goes up and the world goes down,
And the sunshine follows the rain; And yesterday's sneer and yesterday's frown

Can never come over again, Sweet wife.

No, never come over again.
author: Charles Kingsley

quote: You'll never have a quiet world till you knock the patri¬otism out of the human race.
author: George Bernard Shaw

quote: The world is God's world, after all.
author: Charles Kingsley

quote: So many worlds, so much to do, So little done, such things to be.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Everything is for the best in this best of all possible worlds.
author: Voltaire

quote: This world is a comedy to those who think, a tragedy to those who feel.
author: Horace

quote: It is only when men begin to worship that they begin to grow.
author: Calvin Coolidge

quote: And what greater calamity can fall upon a nation than the loss of worship.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote:
Ay, call it holy ground,

The soil where first they trod.

They have left unstained, what there they found
author: Felicia Hemans

quote: Nothing common can seem worthy of you.
author: Gaius Julius Caesar

quote: Worth makes the man, and want of it the fellow; The rest is all but leather and prunello.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: The game is not worth the candle.
author: French Proverb

quote: Of whom the world was not worthy
author: Hebrews, Bible

quote: Two wrongs do not make a right.
author: English Proverb

quote: It is better to suffer wrong than to do it, and happier to be sometimes cheated than not to trust.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: Truth forever on the scaffold, wrong forever on the throne.
author: James Russell Lowell

quote: The remedy for wrongs is to forget them.
author: Publilius Syrus

quote: Ah! happy years! once more who would not be a boy!
author: Lord Byron

quote: Youth comes but once in a lifetime.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote:
How beautiful is youth! how bright it gleams

With its illusions, aspirations, dreams!

Hook of Beginnings, Story without End,

Each maid a heroine, and each man a friend!
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote:
We think our fathers fools, so wise we grow,
Our wiser sons, no doubt, will think us so.
author: Alexander Pope

quote:
If youth but knew, and age were able,

Then poverty would be a fable.
author: French Proverb

quote: Keep true to the dreams of thy youth.
author: Johann Friedrich Von Schiller

quote: As I approve of a youth that has something of the old man in him, so I am no less pleased with an old marl that has something of the youth. He that follows this rule may be old in body, but can never be so in mind.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: Reckless youth makes rueful age.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Youth will be served.
author: English Proverb

quote: Forty is the old age of youth; fifty is the youth of old age.
author: French Proverb

quote: All sorts of allowances are made for the illusions of youth, and none, or almost none, for the disenchantments old age.
author: Robert Louis Balfour Stevenson

quote:
Crabbed age and youth cannot live together;

Youth is full of pleasure, age is full of care;

Youth like summer morn, age like winter weather;

Youth like summer brave, age like winter bare.

Youth is full sport, age's breath is short;

Youth is nimble, age is lame;

Youth is hot and bold, age is weak and cold;

Youth is wild, age is tame.

Age, I do abhor thee; youth, I do adore thee.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: For God's sake give me the young man who has brains enough to make a fool of himself.
author: Robert Louis Balfour Stevenson

quote: Silence is one great art of conversation.
author: William Hazlitt

quote: Conceit causes more conversation than wit.
author: Rochefoucauld

quote: Never hold any one by the button or the hand in order to be heard out; for if people are unwilling to hear you, you had better hold your tongue than them.
author: Lord Chesterfield

quote: A man of courage is also full of faith.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: When moral courage feels that it is in the right, there is no personal daring of which it is incapable.
author: Leigh Hunt

quote: Watch ye, stand fast in the faith, quit you like men, be strong.
author: Corinthians, Bible

quote: One who in a perilous emergency thinks with his legs.
author: Ambrose Gwinnett Bierce

quote: He who fights and runs away May live to fight another day. But he who is in battle slain, Can never rise to fight again.
author: Oliver Goldsmith

quote: A cowardly act! What do I care about that? You may be sure that I should never fear to commit one if it were to my advantage.
author: Napoleon Bonaparte

quote: In the beginning God created the Heaven and the earth. And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters. And God said, Let there be light; and there was light.
author: Genesis, Bible

quote:
Nature they say, doth dote,

And cannot make a man

Save on some worn-out plan,

Repeating us by rote.
author: James Russell Lowell

quote:
All are but parts of one stupendous whole,

Whose body Nature is, and God the soul.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: It is easier to suppose that the universe has existed from all eternity than to conceive a Being beyond its limits capable of creating it.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: The world embarrasses me, and I cannot dream That this watch exists and has no watchmaker.
author: Voltaire

quote: Said the pot to the kettle, "Get away, blackface."
author: Miguel De Cervantes

quote: Critics are the men who have failed in literature and art.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: As a bankrupt thief turns thief-taker in despair, so an unsuccessful author turns critic.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: What a blessed thing it is that nature, when she invented, manufactured and patented her authors, contrived to make critics out of the chips that were left!
author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

quote: I had rather be hissed for a good verse than applauded for a bad one.
author: Victor Hugo

quote:
Man's inhumanity to man

Makes countless thousands mourn!
author: Robert Burns

quote:
It is not linen you're wearing out,

But human creatures' lives.
author: Thomas Hood

quote: All cruelty springs from weakness.
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: I must be cruel, only to be kind.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
On with the dance! Let joy be unconfin'd;
No sleep till morn, when Youth and Pleasure meet.
author: Lord Byron

quote: No man in his senses will dance.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote:
Come and trip it as ye go,

On the light fantastic toe.
author: John Milton

quote: They who love dancing too much seem to have more brains in their feet than in their head.
author: Terence Publius Terentius Afer

quote: What a day may bring a day may take away.
author: Thomas Fuller

quote: Boast not thyself of tomorrow; for thous knowest not what a day may bring forth.
author: Proverbs

quote: Call no man happy till he is dead.
author: Aeschylus

quote: Earth to earth, ashes to ashes, dust to dust, in sure and certain hope of the resurrection.
author: Book Of Common Prayer

quote: In the midst of life we are in death.
author: Book Of Common Prayer

quote: Man that is born of a woman hash but a short time to live, and is full of misery. He cometh up, and is cut down, like a flower; he fleeth as it were a shadow, and never continueth in one stay.
author: Book Of Common Prayer

quote: Death, so called, is a thing which makes men weep, And yet a third of life is pass'd in sleep.
author: Lord Byron

quote:
O death, where is thy sting?

O grave, where is thy victory?
author: Corinthians, Bible

quote: Is death the last sleep? No, it is the last final awakening.
author: Walter Scott

quote: The Lord gave, and the Lord hash taken away; blessed be the name of the Lord.
author: Job, Bible

quote:
Strange—is it not?—that of the myriads who

Before us passed the door of Darkness through,

Not one returns to tell us of the road

Which to discover we must travel too.
author: Omar Khayyam

quote: I am dying, Egypt, dying.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Yet a little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to sleep.
author: Proverbs

quote: I am going to seek a great perhaps; draw the curtain, the farce is played.
author: Francois Rabelais

quote: Till tired, he sleeps, and life's poor play is o'er.
author: Alexander Pope

quote:
To die:—to sleep:

No more; and, by a sleep to say we end

The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks

That flesh is heir to, 'tis a consummation

Devoutly to be wished.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Became him like the leaving it.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Death lies on her, like an untimely frost

Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
First our pleasures die—and then

Our hopes, and then our fears—and when

These are dead, the debt is due,

Dust claims dust—and we die too.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: God's finger touched him, and he slept.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote:
Sunset and evening star,

And one clear call for me!

And may there be no moaning of the bar

When I put out to sea.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Nothing can happen more beautiful than death.
author: Walt Whitman

quote:
For he who lives more lives than one

More deaths than one must die.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: We are never deceived; we deceive ourselves.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote:
Hateful to me as are the gates of hell,

Is he who, hiding one thing in his heart, Utters another.
author: Homer

quote:
`You can fool some of the people all of the time, and all of the people some of the time, but you cannot fool all of the people all the time.
It is double pleasure to deceive the deceiver.
author: La Fontaine

quote: One is easily fooled by that which one loves.
author: Jean-baptiste Poquelin Moliere

quote: We have left undone those things which we ought to have done; and we have done those things which we ought not to have done.
author: Book Of Common Prayer

quote: Whatever is worth doing at all is worth doing well.
author: Lord Chesterfield

quote: Noble deeds that are concealed are most esteemed.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: Heaven ne'er helps the man who will not help himself.
author: Sophocles

quote: It would be folly to argue that the people cannot make political mistakes. They can and do make grave mistakes. They know it, they pay the penalty, but compared with the mistakes which have been made by every kind of autocracy they are unimportant.
author: Calvin Coolidge

quote: The world must be made safe for democracy.
author: Woodrow Wilson

quote: Democracy is the government of the people, by the peo¬ple, for the people.
author: Abraham Lincoln

quote: I believe in Democracy because it releases the energies of every human being.
author: Woodrow Wilson

quote: It is easier to suppress the first desire than to satisfy all that follow it.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: There are two tragedies in life. One is not to get your heart's desire. The other is to get it.
author: George Bernard Shaw

quote: Our desires always increase with our possessions. The knowledge that something remains yet unenjoyed impairs our enjoyment of the good before us.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: Ah love! could you and I with Him conspire To grasp this sorry scheme of things entire, Would not we shatter it to bits—and then Re-mold it nearer to the heart's desire!
author: Omar Khayyam

quote: Every man meets his Waterloo at last.
author: Wendell Phillips

quote: There is a divinity that shapes our ends, Rough-hew them how we will.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Here is the devil-and-all to pay.
author: Miguel De Cervantes

quote:
The devil was sick, the devil a monk would be;

The devil was well, the devil a monk was he.
author: Anonymous

quote:
How art thou fallen from heaven,

O Lucifer, son of the morning!
author: Isaiah

quote: Get thee behind me, Satan.
author: Mark, Bible

quote: He will give the devil his due.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The prince of darkness is a gentleman.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The devil can cite Scripture for his purpose.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The best way out of a difficulty is through it.
author: Anonymous

quote: Many things difficult to design prove easy to perfor¬mance.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: Discretion in speech is more than eloquence.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: A sound discretion is not so much indicated by never making a mistake as by never repeating it.
author: Christian Nestell Bovee

quote: Let your own discretion be your tutor; suit the action to the word, the word to the action.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The better part of valour is discretion.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The dogs eat of the crumbs which fall from their masters' table.
author: Matthew, Bible

quote: Every dog is entitled to one bite.
author: Anonymous

quote: Every dog must have his day.
author: Jonathan Swift

quote: A living dog is better than a dead lion.
author: The Book Of Ecclesiastes

quote: Galileo called doubt the father of invention; it is certainly the pioneer.
author: Christian Nestell Bovee

quote:
Of that there is no manner of doubt-

No probable, possible shadow of doubt—

No possible doubt whatever.
author: William Schwenck Gilbert

quote: We know accurately only when we know little; with knowledge doubt increases.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote: And he that doubteth is damned if he eat.
author: Romans, Bible

quote:
To be, or not to be, that is the question:

Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer

The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune;

Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,

And by opposing end them?
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Our doubts are traitors

And make us lose the good we oft might win

By fearing to attempt.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
There lives more faith in honest doubt,

Believe me, than in half the creeds
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote:
Abou Ben Adhem (may his tribe increase!)

Awoke one night from a deep dream of peace.
author: Leigh Hunt

quote:
We are such stuff
As dreams are made on, and our little life Is rounded with a sleep.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: He is a drunkard who takes more than three glasses, though he be not drunk.
author: Anonymous

quote: Drunkenness is temporary suicide: the happiness that it brings is merely negative, a momentary cessation of unhappiness.
author: Bertrand Russell

quote: Woe unto them that rise up early in the morning, that they may follow strong drink; that continue until night, till wine inflame them.
author: Isaiah

quote: The habit of using ardent spirits by men in office has occasioned more injury to the public, and more trouble to me, than all other causes. Were I to commence my administration again, the first question I would ask respecting a candidate for office would be, Does he use ardent spirits?
author: Thomas Jefferson

quote:
Drink! for you know not whence you came, nor why:
Drink! for you know not why you go, nor where.
author: Omar Khayyam

quote: All excess is ill, but drunkeness is of the worst sort. It spoils health, dismounts the mind, and unmans men. It reveals secrets, is quarrelsome, lascivious, impudent, dangerous and bad.
author: William Penn

quote: There St. John mingles with my friendly bowl The feat of reason and the flow of soul.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: Water is the only drink for a wise man.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: To do my duty in that state of life unto which it shall please God to call me.
author: Book Of Common Prayer

quote: It is thy duty oftentimes to do what thou wouldst not; thy duty, too, to leave undone that thou wouldst do.
author: Thomas A Kempis

quote:
So nigh is grandeur to our dust,

So near is God to man.

When Duty whispers low,

Thou must,

The youth replies, I can.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Let us have faith that right makes might, and in that faith let us, to the end, dare to do our duty as we understand it.
author: Abraham Lincoln

quote: Theirs not to make reply, Theirs not to reason why, Theirs but to do and die.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote:
Not once or twice in our rough island story,

The path of duty was the way to glory.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Let us eat and drink; for tomorrow we shall die.
author: Isaiah

quote: For a man seldom thinks with more earnestness of anything than he does of his dinner.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: Man shall not live by bread alone.
author: Matthew, Bible

quote: Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a stalled ox and hatred therewith.
author: Proverbs

quote: He hath eaten me out of house and home.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: They say fingers were made before forks, and hands before knives.
author: Jonathan Swift

quote: Bread is the staff of life.
author: Jonathan Swift

quote: He who will not economize will have to agonize.
author: Confucius

quote: After order and liberty, economy is one of the highest essentials of a free government.... Economy is always a guarantee of peace.
author: Calvin Coolidge

quote: No man is rich whose expenditure exceeds his means; and no one is poor whose incomings exceed his outgoings.
author: Thomas Chandler Haliburton

quote:
Have more than thou showest,

Speak less than thou knowest.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Schoolhouses are the republican line of fortifications.
author: Horace

quote: What greater or better gift can we offer the republic than to teach and instruct our youth?
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: Training is everything. The peach was once a bitter almond; cauliflower is nothing but cabbage with a college  education.
author: Mark Twain

quote:
The things taught in schools and colleges are not an
education, but the means of education.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote:
'Tis education forms the common mind;
Just as the twig is bent the tree's inclined.
author: Alexander Pope

quote:
Education is the process of driving a set of prejudices down your throat. -MARTIN H. FISCHER
If a man empties his purse into his head, no one can take it from him.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Education is an admirable thing, but it is well to remem¬ber from time to time that nothing that is worth knowing can be taught.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: The manner of your speaking is full as important as the matter, as more people have ears to be tickled than undestandings to judge.
author: Lord Chesterfield

quote: Noise proves nothing. Often a hen who has merely laid an egg cackles as if she laid an asteroid.
author: Mark Twain

quote: True eloquence consists in saying all that is necessary, and nothing but what is necessary.
author: Rochefoucauld

quote: Man is his own worst enemy.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: He who has a thousand friends has not a friend to spare, And he who has one enemy will meet him everywhere.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: None but yourself who are your greatest foe.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: If thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink.
author: Romans, Bible

quote: My prayer to God is a very short one "Oh Lord, make my enemies ridiculous!" God has granted it.
author: Voltaire

quote: A man cannot be too careful in the choice of his enemies.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: The reason why lovers are never wary of one another is this—they are always talking of themselves.
author: Rochefoucauld

quote: Do you wish men to speak well of you? Then never speak well of yourself
author: Blaise Pascal

quote:
Oh, to be in England,

Now that April's there.
author: Robert Browning

quote: I have nothing to offer but blood, toil, tears and sweat.
author: Winston Churchill

quote: We shall go on to the end, we shall fight in France, we shall fight on the seas and oceans, we shall fight with growing confidence and growing strength in the air, we shall defend our Island whatever the cost may be, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets, we shall fight in the hills; we shall never surrender, and even if, which I do not for a moment believe, this Island or a large part of it were subjugated and starving, then our Empire beyond the seas, armed and guarded by the British Fleet, would carry on the struggle, until, in God's good time, the New World, with all its power and might steps forth to the rescue and the liberation of the old.
author: Winston Churchill

quote: Let us therefore brace ourselves to our duties, and so bear ourselves that, if the British Empire and its Com¬monwealth last for a thousand years, men will still say, "This was their finest hour."
author: Winston Churchill

quote: Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few.
author: Winston Churchill

quote: The English nation is never so great as in adversity.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: We are indeed a nation of shopkeepers.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote:
For he might have been a Rooshian

A French or Turk or Proosian,

Or perhaps Itali-an.

But in spite of all temptations

To belong to other nations,

He remains an Englishman.
author: William Schwenck Gilbert

quote: Froth at the top, dregs at bottom, but the middle excel¬lent.
author: Voltaire

quote: There lives more faith in honest doubt, Believe me, than in half the creeds.

And the sky the And the great star early droop'd in the western sky the night,

quote:
Still stands thine ancient sacrifice

quote: A merry heart maketh a cheerful countenance.

quote: Heaven means to be one with God.

quote: There the wicked cease from troubling, and there the weary be at rest.

quote: In my father's house are many mansions.

quote: A heaven on earth.

quote: Lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven.

quote: Earth has no sorrow that heaven cannot heal.

quote: Hero-worship exists, has existed, and will forever exist, universally among mankind.

quote: Hope deferred maketh the heart sick.
author: Proverbs

quote: Who against hope believed in hope.
author: Romans, Bible

quote: You may lead a horse to water but you can't make him drink.
author: English Proverb

quote: You may lead a horse to water but you can't make him drink.
author: English Proverb

quote: A horse! a horse! my kingdom for a horse!
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Our humanity were a poor thing but for the divinity that stirs within us.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: He held his seat; a friend to human race.
author: Homer

quote:
Oh, God! that bread should be so dear,

And flesh and blood so cheap!
author: Thomas Hood

quote:
The world is my country,

all mankind are my brethren,

and to do good is my religion.
author: Thomas Paine

quote: I am not an Athenian, nor a Greek, but a citizen of the world.
author: Socrates

quote: I am a man; I count nothing human foreign to me.
author: Terence Publius Terentius Afer

quote: After crosses and losses, men grow humbler and wiser.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: 'Umble we are, 'umble we have been, 'umble we shall ever be.
author: Charles Dickens

quote: In humility imitate Jesus and Socrates.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: All husbands are alike, but they have different faces so you can tell them apart.
author: Anonymous

quote: A good husband should be deaf and a good wife blind.
author: French Proverb

quote: A good husband is never the first to go to sleep at night or the last to awake in the morning.
author: Honore De Balzac

quote: Men are April when they woo, December when they wed.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: As the husband is, the wife is.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Ideas must work through the brains and the arms of good and brave men, or they are no better than dreams.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: No army can withstand the strength of an idea whose time has come.
author: Victor Hugo

quote: An idea, to be suggestive, must come to the individual with the force of a revelation.
author: William James

quote: It is only liquid currents of thought that move men and the world.
author: Wendell Phillips

quote: I am not ashamed to confess that I am ignorant of wha. I do not know.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: Ignorance never settles a question.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: The human race is governed by its imagination.
author: Napoleon Bonaparte

quote: Imagination disposes of everything; it creates beauty, jus¬tice, and happiness, which is everything in this world.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote:
Imagination is more important than knowledge. -ALBERT EINSTEIN, On Science
Imagination is the eye of the soul.
author: Joseph Joubert

quote: He who has imagination without learning has wings but no feet.
author: Joseph Joubert

quote: What is- human is immortal!
author: Edward George Earle Lytton Bulwer

quote: Immortality is the glorious discovery of Christianity.
author: William Ellery Channing

quote: Then shall the dust return to the earth as it was; and the spirit shall return unto God who gave it.
author: The Book Of Ecclesiastes

quote:
Oh, may I join the choir invisible

Of those immortal dead who live again.
author: George Eliot

quote: Life is the childhood of our immortality.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote: The nearer I approach the end, the plainer I hear around me the immortal symphonies of the worlds which invite me. It is marvelous, yet simple.
author: Victor Hugo

quote: Our hope of immortality does not come from any reli¬gion, but nearly all religions come from that hope.
author: Robert Green Ingersoll

quote: I wish to believe in immortality—I wish to live with you forever.
author: John Keats

quote: No one could ever meet death for his country without the hope of immortality.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote:
For tho' from out our bourne of time and place
The flood may bear me far,
I hope to see my Pilot face to face
When I have cross the bar.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Never did Christ utter a single word attesting to a personal resurrection and a life beyond the grave.
author: Leo Tolstoy

quote: I never thrust my nose into other men's porridge. It is no bread and butter of mine: Every man for himself and God for us all.
author: Miguel De Cervantes

quote: Can anything be so elegant as to have few wants, and to serve them one's self?
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Impossible is a word only to be found in the dictionary of fools.
author: Napoleon Bonaparte

quote: To the timid and hesitating everything is impossible because it seems so.
author: Walter Scott

quote: I would rather sit on a pumpkin, and have it all to myself, than to be crowded on a velvet cushion.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: Thou wert my guide, philosopher, and friend.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: I am a part of all that I have met.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: The humblest individual exerts some influence, either for good or evil, upon others.
author: Henry Ward Beecher

quote: They that know no evil will suspect none.
author: Ben Jonson

quote: Innocence finds not near so much protection as guilt.
author: Rochefoucauld

quote: As innocent as a new-laid egg.
author: William Schwenck Gilbert

quote: No excellent soul is exempt from a mixture of madness.
author: Aristotle

quote: I teach that all men are mad.
author: Horace

quote: Insanity in individuals is something rare—but in groups, parties, nations, and epochs it is the rule.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote:
That he is mad, 'tis true; 'tis true 'tis pity;

And pity 'tis 'tis true.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Whom Jupiter would destroy he first drives mad.
author: Sophocles

quote: Though this be madness, yet there is method in 't.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Open my heart and you will see
Graved inside of it, "Italy."
author: Robert Browning

quote:
On desperate seas long wont to roam,

Thy hyacinth hair, they classic face,

Thy naiad airs have brought me home

To the glory that was Greece

And the grandeur that was Rome.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: He that is not jealous is not in love.
author: St. Augustine

quote: In jealousy there is more self-love than love.
author: Rochefoucauld

quote: O  jealousy! thou magnifier of trifles.
author: Johann Friedrich Von Schiller

quote: Jealousy’s eyes are green.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: Burke said there were Three Estates in Parliament; but, in the Reporters' gallery yonder, there sat a Fourth Estate more important far than they all.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: The best use of a journal is to print the largest practical amount of important truth,—truth which tends to make mankind wiser, and thus happier.
author: Horace

quote: Every newspaper editor owes tribute to the devil.
author: La Fontaine

quote: I fear three newspapers more than a hundred thousand bayonets.
author: Napoleon Bonaparte

quote: We live under a government of men and morning news¬papers.
author: Wendell Phillips

quote: A thing of beauty is a joy forever.
author: John Keats

quote: Sweets with sweets war not, joy delights in joy.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
I have drunken deep of joy,
And I will taste no other wine tonight.
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote: I wish you all the joy that you can wish.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The joyfulness of a man prolongeth his days.
author: The Book Of Ecclesiastes

quote: It is better that a judge should lean on the side of com¬passion than severity.
author: Miguel De Cervantes

quote: A Daniel come to judgment! yea, a Daniel! * wise young judge, how I do honor thee!
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The cold neutrality of an impartial judge.
author: Edmund Burke

quote: Judges are apt to be naive, simple-minded men.
author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

quote:
Thieves for their robbery have authority
When judges steal themselves.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Four things belong to a judge: to hear courteously, to answer wisely, to consider soberly, and to decide impar¬tially.
author: Socrates

quote: One man's word is no man's word; we should quietly hear both sides.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote: Forbear to judge, for we are sinners all.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: I know of no way of judging the future but by the past.
author: Patrick Henry

quote: We judge ourselves by what we feel capable of doing, while others judge us by what we have already done.
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: Judge not, that ye be not judged.
author: Matthew, Bible

quote:
Give every man thine ear, but few thy voice;

Take each man's censure, but reserve thy judgment.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
O judgment! thou are fled to brutish beasts,

And men have lost their reason!
author: William Shakespeare

quote: One cool judgment is worth a thousand hasty councils. The thing to do is to supply light and not heat.
author: Woodrow Wilson

quote: The path of the just is as the shining light, that shineth more and more unto the perfect day.
author: Proverbs

quote: It looks to me to be narrow and pedantic to supply the ordinary ideas of criminal justice to this great public contest. I do not know the method of drawing up an indictment against a whole people.
author: Edmund Burke

quote: The spirits of just men made perfect.
author: Hebrews, Bible

quote: God's mill grinds slow, but sure.
author: George Herbert

quote: The sword of the law should never fall but on those whose guilt is so apparent as to be pronounced by their friends as well as foes.
author: Thomas Jefferson

quote: Render therefore to all their dues.
author: Romans, Bible

quote: He who decides a case without hearing the other side, though he decide justly, cannot be considered just.
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote:
This bond is forfeit;

And lawfully by this the Jew may claim

A pound of flesh.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Thrice is he arm'd that hath his quarrel just,

And he but naked, though lock'd up in steel,

Whose conscience with injustice is corrupted.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Some women blush when they are kissed; some call for the police, some swear; some bite. But the worst are those who laugh.
author: Anonymous

quote:
Gin a body meets a body Comm' through the rye,
Gin a body kiss a body
Need a body cry?
author: Robert Burns

quote:
Come, lay thy head upon my breast,

And I will kiss thee into rest.
author: Lord Byron

quote:
Give me a kisse, and to that kisse a score;

Then to that twenty, adde a hundred more;

A thousand to that hundred; so kisse on,

To make that thousand up a million;

Treble that million, and when that is done,

Let's kisse afresh, as when we first begun.
author: Robert Herrick

quote: A long, long kiss, a kiss of youth, and love.
author: Lord Byron

quote: Stolen kisses are always sweetest.
author: Leigh Hunt

quote:
jenny kissed me when we met,

Jumping from the chair she sat in;

Time, you thief, who love to get

Sweets into your list, put that in.

Say I'm weary, say I'm sad,

Say that health and wealth have missed me;

Say I'm growing old, but add Jenny kissed me.
author: Leigh Hunt

quote:
See! the mountains kiss high heaven,

And the waves clasp one another;

No sister flower would be forgiven

If it disdained its brother;

And the sunlight clasps the earth,

And the moonbeams kiss the sea:—

What are all these kissings worth,

If thou kiss not me?
author: Percy Bysshe Shelley

quote:
Drink to me only with thine eyes

And I will pledge with mine;

Or leave a kiss but in the cup,

And I'll not look for wine.
author: Ben Jonson

quote: To be conscious that you are ignorant is a great step to knowledge.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: For knowledge, too, is itself a power.
author: Francis Bacon

quote:
Strange how much you've got to know

Before you know how little you know.
author: Anonymous

quote: I take all knowledge to be my province.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: He that increaseth knowledge increaseth sorrow.
author: The Book Of Ecclesiastes

quote: Our knowledge is the amassed thought and experience of innumerable minds.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Knowledge is of two kinds. We know a subject ourselves, or we know where we can find information upon it.
author: Samuel Johnson

quote: One cannot know everything.
author: Horace

quote: Better know nothing than half-know many things.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: He that hath knowledge spareth his words.
author: Proverbs

quote: Then I began to think, that it is very true which is com¬monly said, that the one-half of the world knoweth not how the other half liveth.
author: Francois Rabelais

quote: We know what we are, but know not what we may be.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
And seeing ignorance is the curse of God,

Knowledge the wing wherewith we fly to heaven.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Know thyself.
author: Socrates

quote: As for me, all I know is that I know nothing.
author: Socrates

quote: But, for my own part, it was Greek to me.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The whole earth was of one language, and of one speech.
author: Genesis, Bible

quote: No man fully capable of his own language ever masters another.
author: George Bernard Shaw

quote: Language is not an abstract construction of the learned, or of dictionary-makers, but is something arising out of the work, needs, ties, joys, affections, tastes, of long generations of humanity, and has its bases broad and low, close to the ground.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Cae¬sar's.
author: Matthew, Bible

quote: There is no man so good, who, were he to submit all his thoughts and actions to the laws would not deserve hang¬ing ten times in his life.
author: Michel Eyquem De Montaigne

quote: When we think we lead we most are led.
author: Lord Byron

quote: If the blind lead the blind, both shall fall into the ditch
author: Matthew, Bible

quote: A lawyer's opinion is worth nothing unless paid for.
author: English Proverb

quote: The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: A lawyer's opinion is worth nothing unless paid for.
author: English Proverb

quote: The first thing we do, let's kill all the lawyers.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Most good lawyers live well, work hard, and die poor.
author: Daniel Webster

quote: A lawyer must first get on, then get honor, and then get honest.
author: Anonymous

quote: Much learning doth make thee mad.
author: Acts

quote: It is always in season for old men to learn.
author: Aeschylus

quote: Reading maketh a full man; conference a ready man; and writing an exact man.
author: Francis Bacon

quote: Wear your learning like your watch, in a private pocket; and do not pull it out and strike it, merely to show that you have one.
author: Lord Chesterfield

quote: And still they gazed, and still the wonder grew, That one small head should carry all it knew.
author: Oliver Goldsmith

quote:
A little learning is a dangerous thing;

Drink deep, or taste not the Pierian spring;

Their shallow draughts intoxicate the brain,

And drinking largely sobers us again.
author: Alexander Pope

quote: A learned man is an idler who kills time by study.
author: George Bernard Shaw

quote: Men learn while they teach.
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: The people never give up their liberties but under some delusion.
author: Edmund Burke

quote:
Liberty's in every blow!

Let us do or die.
author: Robert Burns

quote: Where the spirit of the Lord is, there is Liberty.
author: Corinthians, Bible

quote: Those who would give up essential liberty to purchase a little temporary safety deserve neither liberty nor safety.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Give me liberty, or give me death.
author: Patrick Henry

quote: The God who gave us life, gave us liberty at the same time.
author: Thomas Jefferson

quote: Give me the liberty to know, to think, to believe, and to utter freely according to conscience, above all other lib¬erties.
author: John Milton

quote: Liberty and Union, now and for ever, one and insepar¬able!
author: Daniel Webster

quote: Life is a jig saw puzzle with most of the pieces missing.
author: Anonymous

quote:
I expect to pass through this world but once. Any good I expect to therefore that I can do, or any kindness that I can show to any fellow creature, let me do it now. Let me not defer
or neglect it, for I shall not pass this way again.
author: Anonymous

quote: I have always in my own thought summed up individual liberty, and business liberty, and every other kind of liberty, in the phrase that is common in the sporting world, "A free field and no favor."
author: Woodrow Wilson

quote: Life is but a day at most.
author: Robert Burns

quote: One life—a little gleam of Time between two Eternities.
author: Thomas Carlyle

quote: For life in general, there is but one decree: youth is a blunder, manhood a struggle, old age a regret.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: Out of sleeping a waking, Out of waking a sleep.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Our whole life is like a play.
author: Ben Jonson

quote: No one is to be despaired of as long as he breathes.
author: Desiderius Erasmus Roterodamus

quote: Dost thou love life? Then do not squander time, for that is the stuff life is made of.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: A useless life is an early death.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote: All that a man hath will he give for his life.
author: Job, Bible

quote: Tell me not, in mournful numbers, Life is but an empty dream!
author: Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

quote: Christian life consists in faith and charity.
author: Martin Luther

quote:
Ah Love! could you and I with him conspire

To grasp this sorry Scheme of Things entire

Would we not shatter it to bits—and then

Re-mould it nearer to the Heart's Desire?
author: Omar Khayyam

quote:
I wish to preach not the doctrine of ignoble ease, but the
doctrine of the strenuous life.
author: Theodore Roosevelt

quote: As is a tale, so is life: not how long it is, but how good it is, is what matters.
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: His saying was: live and let live.
author: Johann Friedrich Von Schiller

quote: Strait is the gate and narrow is the way which leadeth unto life.
author: Matthew, Bible

quote: Out, out, brief candle! Life's but a walking shadow.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: May you live all the days of your life.
author: Jonathan Swift

quote: Let your life lightly dance on the edges of Time like dew on the tip of a leaf.
author: Rabindranath Tagore

quote: The white flower of a blameless life.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: Men know life too early, women know life too late.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: Birds of a feather flock together
author: English Proverb

quote: Like mother, like daughter.
author: English Proverb

quote: Like will to like, each creature loves his kind.
author: Robert Herrick

quote: I shall not look upon his like again
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The true light, which lighteth every man that cometh .into the world.
author: John, Bible

quote: He was a burning and a shining light.
author: John, Bible

quote:
And this I know; whether the one

True Light Kindle to Love, or

Wrath consume me quite,

One flash of it within the

Tavern caught

Better than in the temple lost outright.
author: Omar Khayyam

quote: Nature and Nature's laws lay hid in night: God said, "Let Newton be!" and all was light.
author: Alexander Pope

quote:
O captain! my captain! our fearful trip is done,

The ship has weather'd every rack; the prize we sought is won;

The port is near, the bells I hear, the people all exulting, While follow eyes the steady keel,
the vessel grim and daring;

But O heart! heart! heart!

O the bleeding drops of red,

Where on the deck my captain lies,

Fallen cold and dead.
author: Walt Whitman

quote: His heart was as great as the world, but there was no room in it to hold the memory of a wrong.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote:
Nature, they say, doth dote,

And cannot make a man

Save on some worn-out plan

Repeating us by rote:

For him her Old World moulds aside she threw

And, choosing sweet clay from the breast

Of the unexhausted West,

With stuff untainted shaped a hero new.
author: James Russell Lowell

quote: Logic is logic. That's all I say.
author: Oliver Wendell Holmes

quote: Our first and last love is—self-love.
author: Christian Nestell Bovee

quote:
Oh my luve's like a red, red rose,

That's newly sprung in June;

Oh my luve's like the melodie

That's sweetly played in tune.
author: Robert Burns

quote:
Man's love is of man's life a thing apart,

'Fis woman's whole existence.
author: Lord Byron

quote:
Of all the girls that are so smart

There's none like pretty Sally;

She is the darling of my heart,

And lives in our alley.

There's no love lost between us.
author: Miguel De Cervantes

quote:
All thoughts, all passions, all delights,

Whatever stirs this mortal frame,

All are but ministers of Love,

And feed his sacred flame.
author: Samuel Taylor Coleridge

quote: Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned.
author: William Congreve

quote:
We are all born for love,

... It is the principle of existence and its only end.
author: Benjamin Disraeli

quote: But one always returns to one's first loves.
author: French Proverb

quote: If you would be loved, love and be lovable.
author: Benjamin Franklin

quote: Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends.
author: John, Bible

quote: Love in a hut, with water and a crust, Is—Love, forgive us!—cinders, ashes, dust.
author: John Keats

quote:
Sing, for faith and hope are high

None so true as you and I

Sing the Lovers' Litany:

"Love like ours can never die!"
author: Rudyard Kipling

quote: The reason why lovers and their mistresses never tire of being together is that they are always talking of them¬selves.
author: Rochefoucauld

quote: He who loves not wine, woman, and song, Remains a fool his whole life long.
author: Martin Luther

quote: All mankind love a lover.
author: Ralph Waldo Emerson

quote: Whom the Lord loveth he chasteneth.
author: Hebrews, Bible

quote: There is no fear in love; but perfect love casteth out fear.
author: John, Bible

quote: Love's like the measles—all the worse when it comes late in life.
author: George Norman Douglas

quote: So dear I love him, that with him all deaths I could endure, without him live no life.
author: John Milton

quote: Love is often a fruit of marriage.
author: Jean-baptiste Poquelin Moliere

quote: But there's nothing half so sweet in life As love's young dream.
author: Thomas Moore

quote: The only victory over love is flight.
author: Napoleon Bonaparte

quote: Love—a grave mental disease.
author: Plato

quote: Better is a dinner of herbs where love is, than a stalled ox and hatred therewith.
author: Proverbs

quote: Love is the fulfilling of the law.
author: Romans, Bible

quote: Men have died from time to time, and worms have eaten them—but not for love.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Ay me! for aught that I ever could read,

Could ever hear by tale or history,

The course of true love never did run smooth.
author: William Shakespeare

quote:
Give me my Romeo; and, when he shall die.

Take him, and cut him out in little stars,

And he will make the face of heaven so fine,

That all the world will be in love with night,

And pay no worship to the garish sun.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Love sought is good, but given unsought is better.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: The fickleness of the woman I love is equalled by the infernal constancy of the women who love me.
author: George Bernard Shaw

quote:
'Tis better to have loved and lost,

Than never to have loved at all.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote:
Werther had a love for Charlotte,

Such as words could never utter;

Would you know how first he met her?

She was cutting bread and butter.
author: William Makepeace Thackeray

quote: Peter said, Ananias, why hath Satan filled thine heart to lie to the Holy Ghost? ... And Ananias hearing these words fell down, and gave up the ghost.
author: Acts

quote: A liar is not believed even though he tell the truth.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: Show me a liar, and I will show thee a thief.
author: George Herbert

quote: Who dares think one thing, and another tell, My heart detests him as the gates of hell.
author: Homer

quote:
The liar's punishment is not in the least that he is not believed, but that he cannot believe anyone else. -GEORGE BERNARD SHAW
That a lie which is half a truth is ever the blackest of lies;
That a lie which is all a lie may be met and fought with outright
But a lie which is part a truth is a harder matter to fight.
author: Alfred Tennyson

quote: It is my principle that the will of the majority should always prevail.
author: Thomas Jefferson

quote: One, on God's side, is a majority.
author: Wendell Phillips

quote: One with the law is a majority.
author: Calvin Coolidge

quote: A man's a man for a' that!
author: Robert Burns

quote: I think that God, in creating man, somewhat overestimated his ability.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: My most brilliant achievement was my ability to be able to persuade my wife to marry me.
author: Winston Churchill

quote: Ability will never catch up with the demand for it.
author: Confucius

quote: I will not be concerned at other men's not knowing me;I will be concerned at my own want of ability.
author: Confucius

quote: The superior man is distressed by the limitations of his ability; he is not distressed by the fact that men do not recognize the ability that he has.
author: Confucius

quote: Wealth is the ability to fully experience life.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: Absence from those we love is self from self - a deadly banishment.
author: William Shakespeare

quote: Absence and death are the same - only that in death there is no suffering.
author: Theodore Roosevelt

quote: Absence - that common cure of love.
author: Lord Byron

quote: A slender acquaintance with the world must convince every man that actions, not words, are the true criterion of the attachment of friends.
author: George Washington

quote: Acquaintance. A person whom we know well enough to borrow from, but not well enough to lend to.
author: Ambrose Gwinnett Bierce

quote: Depth of friendship does not depend on length of acquaintance.
author: Rabindranath Tagore

quote: An acquaintance that begins with a compliment is sure to develop into a real friendship
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: Where a blood relation sobs, an intimate friend should choke up, a distant acquaintance should sigh, a stranger should merely fumble sympathetically with his handkerchief.
author: Mark Twain

quote: Not until you become a stranger to yourself will you be able to make acquaintance with the Friend.
author: Mark Twain

quote: A truly good book teaches me better than to read it. I must soon lay it down, and commence living on its hint. What I began by reading, I must finish by acting.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: Stop acting as if life is a rehearsal. Live this day as if it were your last. The past is over and gone. The future is not guaranteed.
author: Wayne Dyer

quote: Thinking is easy, acting is difficult, and to put one's thoughts into action is the most difficult thing in the world.
author: Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe

quote: Thus it shall befall Him, who to worth in women over-trusting, Lets her will rule: restraint she will not brook; And left to herself, if evil thence ensue She first his weak indulgence will accuse.
author: John Milton

quote: So hand in hand they passed, the loveliest pair that ever since in love's embraces met -- Adam, the goodliest man of men since born his sons; the fairest of her daughters Eve.
author: John Milton

quote: He has all the virtues I dislike and none of the vices I admire.
author: Winston Churchill

quote: Woman is not made to be the admiration of all, but the happiness of one.
author: Edmund Burke

quote: He who knows how to flatter also knows how to slander.
author: Napoleon Bonaparte

quote: There is an innocence in admiration: it occurs in one who has not yet realized that they might one day be admired.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Admiration for a quality or an art can be so strong that it deters us from striving to possess it.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: I was very pleased with your kind letter. Until now I never dreamed of being something like a hero. But since you've given me the nomination I feel that I am one.
author: Albert Einstein

quote: Never to suffer would never to have been blessed.
author: Edgar Allan Poe

quote: He stepped down, avoiding any long look at her as one avoids long looks at the sun, but seeing her as one sees the sun, without looking.
author: Leo Tolstoy

quote: However mean your life is, meet it and live it.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: I love those who can smile in trouble...
author: Leonardo Da Vinci

quote: Difficulties strengthen the mind, as labor does the body.
author: Lucius Annaeus Seneca

quote: The most truthful part of a newspaper is the advertisements.
author: Thomas Jefferson

quote: It is foolish to tear one’s hair in grief, as though sorrow would be made less by baldness.
author: Marcus Tullius Cicero

quote: My advice to you is get married: if you find a good wife you'll be happy; if not, you'll become a philosopher.
author: Socrates

quote: I always pass on good advice. It is the only thing to do with it. It is never of any use to oneself.
author: Oscar Wilde

quote: Always acknowledge a fault. This will throw those in authority off their guard and give you an opportunity to commit more.
author: Mark Twain

quote: There are old heads in the world who cannot help me by their example or advice to live worthily and satisfactorily to myself; but I believe that it is in my power to elevate myself this very hour above the common level of my life.
author: Henry David Thoreau

quote: When something an affliction happens to you, you either let it defeat you, or you defeat it.
author: Jean-jacques Rousseau

quote: Vanity of science. Knowledge of physical science will not console me for ignorance of morality in time of affliction, but knowledge of morality will always console me for ignorance of physical science.
author: Blaise Pascal

quote: I have striven not to laugh at human actions, not to weep at them, nor to hate them, but to understand them.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: All happiness or unhappiness solely depends upon the quality of the object to which we are attached by love.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: I have striven not to laugh at human actions, not to weep at them, nor to hate them, but to understand them.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: How would it be possible if salvation were ready to our hand, and could without great labor be found, that it should be by almost all men neglected? But all things excellent are as difficult as they are rare.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: Only that thing is free which exists by the necessities of its own nature, and is determined in its actions by itself alone.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: So long as a man imagines that he cannot do this or that, so long as he is determined not to do it; and consequently so long as it is impossible to him that he should do it.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: Sin cannot be conceived in a natural state, but only in a civil state, where it is decreed by common consent what is good or bad.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: I would warn you that I do not attribute to nature either beauty or deformity, order or confusion. Only in relation to our imagination can things be called beautiful or ugly, well-ordered or confused.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: If men were born free, they would, so long as they remained free, form no conception of good and evil.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: Be not astonished at new ideas; for it is well known to you that a thing does not therefore cease to be true because it is not accepted by many.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: The highest activity a human being can attain is learning for understanding, because to understand is to be free.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: No matter how thin you slice it, there will always be two sides.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: When you say that if I deny, that the operations of seeing, hearing, attending, wishing, &c., can be ascribed to God, or that they exist in Him in any eminent fashion, you do not know what sort of God mine is; I suspect that you believe there is no greater perfection than such as can be explained by the aforesaid attributes. I am not astonished; for I believe that, if a triangle could speak, it would say, in like manner, that God is eminently triangular, while a circle would say that the divine nature is eminently circular. Thus each would ascribe to God its own attributes, would assume itself to be like God, and look on everything else as ill-shaped.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: We do not need to be shoemakers to know if our shoes fit, and just as little have we any need to be professionals to acquire knowledge of matters of universal interest.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: An idea is always a generalization, and generalization is a property of thinking. To generalize means to think.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: Animals are in possession of themselves; their soul is in possession of their body. But they have no right to their life, because they do not will it.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: To him who looks upon the world rationally, the world in its turn presents a rational aspect. The relation is mutual.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: To him who looks upon the world rationally, the world in its turn presents a rational aspect. The relation is mutual.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: Once the state has been founded, there can no longer be any heroes. They come on the scene only in uncivilized conditions.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: Nothing great in the world has ever been accomplished without passion.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: To be independent of public opinion is the first formal condition of achieving anything great.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: Only one man ever understood me, and he didn't understand me.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: The state of man's mind, or the elementary phase of mind which he so far possesses, conforms precisely to the state of the world as he so far views it.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: The definition of the freedom of the press as freedom to say and write what one pleases, is parallel to the one of freedom in general, viz., as freedom to do what one pleases. Such a view belongs to the uneducated crudity and superficiality of naïve thinking.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: The laws of morality are not accidental, but are essentially Rational. It is the very object of the State that what is essential in the practical activity of men, and in their dispositions, should be duly recognized; that it should have a manifest existence, and maintain its position.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: The significance of that 'absolute commandment', know thyself — whether we look at it in itself or under the historical circumstances of its first utterance — is not to promote mere self-knowledge in respect of the particular capacities, character, propensities, and foibles of the single self. The knowledge it commands means that of man's genuine reality — of what is essentially and ultimately true and real — of spirit as the true and essential being.
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: Too fair to worship, too divine to love
author: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel

quote: It is not a lack of love, but a lack of friendship that makes unhappy marriages.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Without music, life would be a mistake.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: I'm not upset that you lied to me, I'm upset that from now on I can't believe you.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: You have your way. I have my way. As for the right way, the correct way, and the only way, it does not exist.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: In heaven, all the interesting people are missing.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Whoever fights monsters should see to it that in the process he does not become a monster. And if you gaze long enough into an abyss, the abyss will gaze back into you.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Sometimes people don't want to hear the truth because they don't want their illusions destroyed.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: The individual has always had to struggle to keep from being overwhelmed by the tribe. If you try it, you will be lonely often, and sometimes frightened. But no price is too high to pay for the privilege of owning yourself.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: I cannot believe in a God who wants to be praised all the time.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: He who has a why to live for can bear almost any how.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Faith: not wanting to know what the truth is.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: The snake which cannot cast its skin has to die. As well the minds which are prevented from changing their opinions; they cease to be mind.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Is man merely a mistake of God's? Or God merely a mistake of man?
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Every deep thinker is more afraid of being understood than of being misunderstood.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Be careful, lest in casting out your demon you exorcise the best thing in you.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: The true man wants two things: danger and play. For that reason he wants woman, as the most dangerous plaything.”
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: The higher we soar the smaller we appear to those who cannot fly.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Ah, women. They make the highs higher and the lows more frequent.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: A thinker sees his own actions as experiments and questions--as attempts to find out something. Success and failure are for him answers above all.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Meaning and morality of One's life come from within oneself. Healthy, strong individuals seek self expansion by experimenting and by living dangerously. Life consists of an infinite number of possibilities and the healthy person explores as many of them as posible. Religions that teach pity, self-contempt, humility, self-restraint and guilt are incorrect. The good life is ever changing, challenging, devoid of regret, intense, creative and risky.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: All things are subject to interpretation. Whichever interpretation prevails at a given time is a function of power and not truth.
author: Friedrich Nietzsche

quote: Love is not primarily a relationship to a specific person; it is an attitude, an ordination of character which determines the relatedness of the person to the whole world as a whole, not toward one object of love.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Immature love says: 'I love you because I need you.' Mature love says 'I need you because I love you.'
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Love is a decision, it is a judgment, it is a promise. If love were only a feeling, there would be no basis for the promise to love each other forever. A feeling comes and it may go. How can I judge that it will stay forever, when my act does not involve judgment and decision.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: If a person loves only one other person and is indifferent to all others, his love is not love but a symbiotic attachment, or an enlarged egotism.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: It is naively assumed that the fact that the majority of people share certain ideas and feelings proves the validity of these ideas and feelings. Nothing could be further from the truth. Consensual validation as such has no bearing on reason or mental health.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Love means to commit oneself without guarantee, to give oneself completely in the hope that our love will produce love in the loved person. Love is an act of faith, and whoever is of little faith is also of little love.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Freedom is not a constant attribute which we either "have" or "have not." In fact, there is no such thing as "freedom" except as a word and an abstract concept. There is only one reality: the act of freeing ourselves in the process of making choices.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: To die is poignantly bitter, but the idea of having to die without having lived is unbearable.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: There is nothing inhuman, evil, or irrational which does not give some comfort, provided it is shared by a group.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: The real opposition is that between the ego-bound man, whose existence is structured by the principle of having, and the free man, who has overcome his egocentricity.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Our conscious motivations, ideas, and beliefs are a blend of false information, biases, irrational passions, rationalizations, prejudices, in which morsels of truth swim around and give the reassurance albeit false, that the whole mixture is real and true. The thinking processes attempt to organize this whole cesspool of illusions according to the laws of plausibility. This level of consciousness is supposed to reflect reality; it is the map we use for organizing our life.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: The only truly affluent are those who do not want more than they have.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: That millions of people share the same forms of mental pathology does not make these people sane.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Freedom does not mean license.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Could it be that only those things are considered worthy of being learned with which one can earn money or prestige, and that love, which "only" profits the soul, but is profitless in the modern sense, is a luxury we have no right to spend energy on?
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Just as modern mass production requires the standardization of commodities, so the social process requires standardization of man, and this standardization is called equality.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: We all dream; we do not understand our dreams, yet we act as if nothing strange goes on in our sleep minds, strange at least by comparison with the logical, purposeful doings of our minds when we are awake.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: We should free ourselves from the narrowness of being related only to those familiar to us, either by the fact that they are blood relations or, in a larger sense, that we eat the same food, speak the same language, and have the same “ common sense.” Knowing men in the sense of compassionate and empathetic knowledge requires that we get rid of the narrowing ties of a given society, race or culture and penetrate to the depth of that human reality in which we are all nothing but human. True compassion and knowledge of man has been largely underrated as a revolutionary factor in the development of man, just as art has been. It is a noteworthy phenomenon that in the development of capitalism and its ethics, compassion (or mercy) ceases to be a virtue.
author: Erich Fromm

quote: Modern capitalism needs men who cooperate smoothly and in large numbers; who want to consume more and more; and whose tastes are standardized and can be easily influenced and anticipated. It needs men who feel free and independent, not subject to any authority or principle or conscience- yet willing to be commanded, to do what is expected of them, to fit into the social machine without friction; who can be guided without force, led without leaders, prompted without aim- except the one to make good, to be on the move, to function, to go ahead.
author: Erich Fromm

quote:
Is there not a God, or some being, by whatever name I may designate him, who causes these thoughts to arise in my mind? But why suppose

such a being, for it may be I myself am capable of producing them? Am I, then, at least not something? But I before denied that I possessed

senses or a body; I hesitate, however, for what follows from that? Am I so dependent on the body and the senses that without these I cannot

exist? But I had the persuasion that there was absolutely nothing in the world, that there was no sky and no earth, neither minds nor

bodies; was I not, therefore, at the same time, persuaded that I did not exist? Far from it; I assuredly existed, since I was persuaded.

But there is I know not what being, who is possessed at once of the highest power and the deepest cunning, who is constantly employing all

his ingenuity in deceiving me. Doubtless, then, I exist, since I am deceived; and, let him deceive me as he may, he can never bring it

about that I am nothing, so long as I shall be conscious that I am something.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: Doubt is the origin of wisdom.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: I had become aware, as early as my college days, that no opinion, however absurd and incredible can be imagined, that has not been held by one of the philosophers.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: Cogito ergo sum. (I think, therefore I exist.)
author: Rene Descartes

quote: If you would be a real seeker after truth, it is necessary that at least once in your life you doubt, as far as possible, all things.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: The reading of all good books is like conversation with the finest men of past centuries.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: Common sense is the most widely shared commodity in the world, for every man is convinced that he is well supplied with it.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: I suppose therefore that all things I see are illusions; I believe that nothing has ever existed of everything my lying memory tells me. I think I have no senses. I believe that body, shape, extension, motion, location are functions. What is there then that can be taken as true? Perhaps only this one thing, that nothing at all is certain.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: For I found myself embarrassed with so many doubts and errors that it seemed to me that the effort to instruct myself had no effect other than the increasing discovery of my own ignorance
author: Rene Descartes

quote: Except our own thoughts, there is nothing absolutely in our power.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: There is nothing more ancient than the truth.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: But I cannot forget that, at other times I have been deceived in sleep by similar illusions; and, attentively considering those cases, I perceive so clearly that there exist no certain marks by which the state of waking can ever be distinguished from sleep, that I feel greatly astonished; and in amazement I almost persuade myself that I am now dreaming.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: To know what people really think, pay attention to what they do, rather than what they say.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: although we very clearly see the sun, we ought not therefore to determine that it is only of the size which our sense of sight presents; and we may very distinctly imagine the head of a lion joined to the body of a goat, without being therefore shut up to the conclusion that a chimaera exists; for it is not a dictate of reason that what we thus see or imagine is in reality existent; but it plainly tells us that all our ideas or notions contain in them some truth.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: In God there is an infinitude of things which I cannot comprehend, nor possibly even reach in any way by thought; for it is the nature of the infinite that my nature, which is finite and limited, should not comprehend it.
author: Rene Descartes

quote: The supreme mystery of despotism, its prop and stay, is to keep men in a state of deception, and with the specious title of religion to cloak the fear by which they must be held in check, so that they will fight for their servitude as if for salvation.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: Further conceive, I beg, that a stone, while continuing in motion, should be capable of thinking and knowing, that it is endeavoring, as far as it can, to continue to move. Such a stone, being conscious merely of its own endeavor and not at all indifferent, would believe itself to be completely free, and would think that it continued in motion solely because of its own wish. This is that human freedom, which all boast that they possess, and which consists solely in the fact, that men are conscious of their own desire, but are ignorant of the causes whereby that desire has been determined.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: The more you struggle to live, the less you live. Give up the notion that you must be sure of what you are doing. Instead, surrender to what is real within you, for that alone is sure....you are above everything distressing.
author: Baruch Spinoza

quote: The only defense against the world is a thorough knowledge of it.
author: John Locke

quote: New opinions are always suspected, and usually opposed, without any other reason but because they are not common.
author: John Locke

quote: To love truth for truth's sake is the principal part of human perfection in this world, and the seed-plot of all other virtues.
author: John Locke

quote: No man's knowledge here can go beyond his experience.
author: John Locke

quote: There is frequently more to be learned from the unexpected questions of a child than the discourses of men.
author: John Locke

quote: To prejudge other men's notions before we have looked into them is not to show their darkness but to put out our own eyes.
author: John Locke

quote: One unerring mark of the love of truth is not entertaining any proposition with greater assurance than the proofs it is built upon will warrant.
author: John Locke

quote: Beauty is no quality in things themselves: It exists merely in the mind which contemplates them; and each mind perceives a different beauty.
author: David Hume

quote: Generally speaking, the errors in religion are dangerous; those in philosophy only ridiculous.
author: David Hume
